newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO extends gains on crude rise.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO extends gains on crude rise.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices on Monday were assessed higher on crude gains, healthy Chinese demand and limited supplies, traders said.
Traders said prices on Monday were expected to rise above Friday's quotes. High sulphur 180-cst fuel oil prices were assessed at $119-$121 on Friday.
Chinese appetite for oil is propping up prices, traders said. Chinese bids were heard at $7-$8 per tonne over Singapore spot quotes on a cost-and-freight basis to south China.
Offers from South Korea were heard at $2 per tonne on a free-on-board basis.
A Singapore trader was also seen buying any available supplies, said a trader from a major oil firm.
In the swaps market, traders said Chinese state-trader Sinochem has been particularly active in recent weeks. January swaps were quoted at $120.50/$122, up from $119.25/$120.25 on Friday.
